docs.title: UmBootstrap
docs.text: UmBootstrap is an Umbraco 17 starter kit that provides a solid foundation for building Bootstrap-based websites.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Umbraco 17 - Latest version of the CMS
  • Bootstrap 5 - Responsive CSS framework
  • Block Grid - Pre-configured block grid components with live previews
  • uSync - Content and configuration synchronisation out of the box
  • ModelsBuilder - Strongly-typed models in SourceCodeAuto mode

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
Install the template and create a new project:

dotnet new install UmBootstrap.DotNet.Template
dotnet new umbootstrap -n MyProject
cd MyProject
dotnet run

See Getting Started for detailed instructions.

docs.title: Layouts
docs.text:
Container elements for page structure:

Layout Description layout12 Full-width single column layout48 1/3 + 2/3 two column layout66 50/50 two column layout84 2/3 + 1/3 two column

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
Content blocks for building pages:

  • Rich Text Editor
  • Images
  • FAQs (accordion)
  • Tabs
  • Internal Links (various styles)
  • Navigation descendants
  • HTML/Code blocks
  • Contact form

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• .NET 10 SDK or later
  • A code editor (Visual Studio, VS Code, Rider)

docs.title: Option 1: .NET CLI (Recommended)
docs.text:
# Install the template
dotnet new install UmBootstrap.DotNet.Template

# Create a new project
dotnet new umbootstrap -n MyProject

# Navigate to the project
cd MyProject

# Run the site
dotnet run

docs.title: Option 2: Visual Studio
docs.text:
1. Install the template: dotnet new install UmBootstrap.DotNet.Template
  2. Open Visual Studio
  3. Create New Project
  4. Search for "UmBootstrap"
  5. Follow the wizard

docs.title: First Run
docs.text:
On first run, Umbraco will:

  1. Create the database (SQLite by default)
  2. Import content via uSync
  3. Launch the backoffice setup wizard

docs.title: Default Setup
docs.text:
• Database: SQLite (stored in umbraco/Data/)
  • Admin credentials: Set during first run
  • Content: Sample pages imported via uSync

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
MyProject/
├── Views/
│   ├── Partials/
│   │   ├── blockgrid/     # Block grid component views
│   │   └── blocklist/     # Block list component views
│   ├── Home.cshtml        # Home page template
│   └── WebPage.cshtml     # Generic page template
├── umbraco/
│   ├── Models/            # Generated C# models
│   └── Data/              # Database files
├── uSync/v17/             # Content/config sync files
├── wwwroot/               # Static assets (CSS, JS, images)
└── appsettings.json       # Configuration

docs.title: BlockPreview
docs.text:
Block previews are configured in appsettings.json:

{
  "BlockPreview": {
    "BlockGrid": {
      "Enabled": true,
      "ContentTypes": ["featureRichTextEditor", "featureImage"],
      "Stylesheets": ["/css/Index.css"]
    }
  }
}

Add your feature element types to ContentTypes to enable live previews in the backoffice.

docs.title: uSync
docs.text:
uSync automatically imports content on first boot:

{
  "uSync": {
    "Settings": {
      "ImportOnFirstBoot": true
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Installed Packages
docs.text:
UmBootstrap includes the following Umbraco community packages out of the box.

Package Version Description BlockPreview 5.1.0 Live block previews in the backoffice UmbNav 4.0.3-beta0001 Navigation menu builder uSync 17.0.2 Content and configuration synchronisation

docs.title: BlockPreview
docs.text: Package Umbraco.Community.BlockPreview Version 5.2.1 Source GitHub

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text: BlockPreview renders live previews of block grid and block list components directly in the Umbraco backoffice. Instead of seeing generic block placeholders, content editors see a rendered preview of each block using the same Razor partial views as the front end.

docs.title: How UmBootstrap Uses It
docs.text:
BlockPreview is configured programmatically in Program.cs. At startup, reflection is used to scan all ModelsBuilder-generated types and automatically exclude any whose alias starts with "layout" via IgnoredContentTypes:

.AddBlockPreview(options =>
{
    var layoutAliases = typeof(Layout12).Assembly.GetTypes()
        .Where(t => t.Namespace == "Umbraco.Cms.Web.Common.PublishedModels")
        .Select(t => t.GetField("ModelTypeAlias",
            BindingFlags.Public | BindingFlags.Static)?.GetValue(null) as string)
        .Where(alias => alias != null && alias.StartsWith("layout"))
        .ToList();

    options.BlockGrid = new()
    {
        Enabled = true,
        IgnoredContentTypes = layoutAliases!,
        Stylesheets = ["/css/Index.css"]
    };
})

Layout elements (layout12, layout66, etc.) are automatically excluded — they only contain areas and don't need previews. All feature element types get previews automatically.

docs.title: Adding Previews for New Blocks
docs.text:
When you create a new feature element type:

  1. Create the Razor partial view in Views/Partials/blockgrid/
  2. That's it — BlockPreview will automatically include it

New layout types are also handled automatically as long as they follow the layout* naming convention.

docs.title: UmbNav
docs.text: Package Umbraco.Community.UmbNav Version 4.0.3-beta0001 Source GitHub

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text:
UmbNav is a navigation menu builder for Umbraco. It provides a drag-and-drop property editor in the backoffice that lets content editors build and manage navigation menus with support for:

  • Internal links to Umbraco content
  • External URLs
  • Nested/hierarchical menu items
  • Custom labels and CSS classes

docs.title: How UmBootstrap Uses It
docs.text: UmbNav powers the main site navigation. The property editor is added to document types that need a navigation menu, and the front-end renders the menu structure using Bootstrap's navbar component.

docs.title: uSync
docs.text: Package uSync Version 17.0.2 Source GitHub Docs docs.jumoo.co.uk/usync

docs.title: What It Does
docs.text: uSync serialises Umbraco configuration and content to disk as files. This allows document types, data types, templates, content, and other Umbraco settings to be stored in source control and shared across environments.

docs.title: How UmBootstrap Uses It
docs.text:
UmBootstrap uses uSync to ship the starter kit's content and configuration. The sync files live in uSync/v17/ and are imported automatically on first boot:

{
  "uSync": {
    "Settings": {
      "ImportOnFirstBoot": true
    }
  }
}

This means when a new project is created from the template, all document types, data types, content, and media are set up automatically without manual configuration.

docs.title: What Gets Synced
docs.text:
The uSync/v17/ folder contains:

  • ContentTypes — Document types and element types
  • DataTypes — Property editor configurations
  • Content — Sample pages and content
  • Media — Uploaded media items
  • MediaTypes — Media type definitions
  • Templates — Razor view registrations
  • Languages — Language configurations
